thread.title: Tourist films a Cathay Pacific flight making an emergency landing
thread.title_full: Tourist films a Cathay Pacific flight making an emergency landing

title: Tourist films a Cathay Pacific flight making an emergency landing
text:
Tourist films a Cathay Pacific flight making an emergency landing Last updated 10:11, August 3 2015 One City At A Time/YouTube 
Passenger Ethan Williams has filmed the terrifying moment his flight was forced to make an emergency landing. 
A British passenger has filmed the alarming moment his flight was forced to make an emergency landing. 
Ethan Williams was on board Cathay Pacific flight CX844 from Hong Kong to Los Angeles when cabin crew instructed passengers to put their life jackets on. 
In the four-minute video uploaded to Youtube , Williams is heard saying: "I'm not sure what's happening, but there's something going on, on this flight [sic]," Youtube/One City At A Time 
Passengers were told put on their life jackets and adopt the brace position. 
"All the flight attendants are running around like crazy and there's warning signs going off. 
30 seconds into the video Williams confirms that the flight is being forced to make an emergency landing. 
"We've just had an announcement, we've got an emergency landing. We've not been told what is going on but we've got an emergency landing." The moment our plane had to perform a 180degree turn at the end of the Shemya runway before heading to Anchor #CX884 pic.twitter.com/FbELNEPKSc — Ethan Williams (@eth_will) July 30, 2015 
Cabin crew can be heard telling passengers to remove their shoes and store their jackets under the seat in front of them. 
The footage shows Williams putting his life jacket on, as a crew member is heard instructing passengers on the "brace" position. 
"We've started to descend. We're flying from Hong Kong to LA, so I don't know what land there is between there." A few moments later the crew announce that they will be making a normal landing and not a water landing. "That's really good news, but we still don't know why. It doesn't really matter as long as we land OK". Williams said. And that's touchdown! We've all landed safely into LAX #CX884 — Ethan Williams (@eth_will) July 30, 2015 
No one was injured and the jet landed safely, to the applause of relieved passengers.. Ad Feedback 
Cathay Pacific confirmed that an equipment cooling fan failed, forcing the flight to land at a remote air base in the Aleutian Islands. 
Smoke was detected around the cockpit area, prompting the captain of Flight CX884 to divert to Eareckson Air Station on Alaska's Shemya Island, the airline said. "Once again, we apologise to passengers for the delay, but everybody is safe and sound, and that's what's the most important," Cathay Pacific spokeswoman Jennifer Pearson said. "They're now at their destination." We all got handed one of these upon boarding. @cathaypacific thank you for looking after us! #CX884 pic.twitter.com/KYyE1HMlld — Ethan Williams (@eth_will) July 30, 2015 
The plane was deemed serviceable and left the treeless, tundra-covered island to fly the 276 passengers and 18 crew members to Anchorage, 2414 kilometres away. - Stuff
